Interested in becoming a substitute teacher in Missouri? Don't have the required 60 hours of college level credits?

Beginning in September, 2020, you can obtain your certification to become a substitute teacher in Missouri through completing Frontline Substitute Teacher Training, as approved by the Missouri Department of Elementary and Secondary Education. The training consists of approximately 22 hours of content specifically designed for substitute teachers an aligned to Missouri Teaching Standards. Upon completion, you'll receive a Frontlne Certificate of Completion demonstrating your readiness to obtain a Missouri substitute teacher license, but more importantly, you'll have the confidence of knowing you're prepared to enter the classroom! Click the link below to learn more.

https://www.frontlineeducation.com/pages/resources/modese/

*Students riding buses will be contacted by the bus driver so they can give you an approximate arrival time.

*Any parent picking up their child will need to be in front of the New Gym area by 2:50pm.

*Make sure and call the office before 2pm if you are changing transportation arrangements any day during summer school.

We will see the students that are registered for summer school on Monday!

Mrs. Schroeder would like to say Happy Better Hearing and Speech Month! Thank you so much for allowing me to share all things communication with our school and community! I LOVE working with my students on these skills to help them succeed in the classroom. I miss them dearly and look forward to seeing them again soon!

Speech pathologists can work in many settings, including hospitals, nursing homes, clinics, and of course, schools!

School-based speech-language pathologists work with students not only on making sounds like /r/ and /s/, but also on academic and curriculum-related skills including written expression, reading comprehension, abstract reasoning and social language. All of these skills are essential to learning.

March 2 at 3:31 PM ·

St. Clair High School's FFA club visited Lonedell students on a very cold Friday last week. They presented the Food For America program. According to https://www.ffa.org, this is an educational program focusing on agricultural literacy in elementary schools and communities. It is a program developed to assist FFA members and all agricultural education students in leadership skill development as they reach out to youth, peers and their entire communities by sharing the world of agriculture.

Our students enjoyed the animals most of all. It was nice to see so many Lonedell graduates take leadership roles in this program!

post_text: Read to Succeed is a free reading program for students in grades K-6 that allows students to earn a ticket to Six Flags just by reading for fun! Students are required to read 6 hours (360 minutes) in order to qualify for a free daily admission ticket. Students wishing to participate in the program will need to log their minutes then enter them online using their teacher's classroom code. As an additional incentive to read, students can earn bonus awards such as discounts on additional tickets for family members, Season Passes or Memberships by reading more than six hours. Please watch for the Read to Succeed information to come home with your child soon. The deadline for submission of the eReading log is April 8, 2020. Students who meet reading requirements will receive their tickets in May. Contact Tiger Dierker at tdierker@lonedell.org with questions and Happy Reading!
